verses.text: Then Joshua called together the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh,
verses.comment: Joshua addresses the eastern tribes who had served faithfully.

verses.text: and said to them, “You have kept everything that Moses the servant of the LORD commanded you, and have obeyed me in all that I have commanded you.
verses.comment: Faithfulness to Moses and Joshua is emphasized. The phrase 'obeyed me' replaces 'obeyed my voice'.

verses.text: You have not abandoned your brothers these many days, up to this day, but have kept the charge of the commandment of the LORD your God.
verses.comment: “Charge” retains the sense of responsibility entrusted to them.

verses.text: Now the LORD your God has given rest to your brothers, just as He promised them. So now return and go to your tents, to the land of your possession, which Moses the servant of the LORD gave you on the east side of the Jordan.
verses.comment: ‘Rest’ used in sense of peace. ‘On the east side of the Jordan’ clarified for readability.

verses.text: Only take careful heed to follow the commandment and the law that Moses the servant of the LORD commanded you: to love the LORD your God, to walk in all His ways, to keep His commandments, to cling to Him, and to serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul.”
verses.comment: ‘Cling to Him’ translates ‘hold fast to Him’ for clarity.

verses.text: So Joshua blessed them and sent them away, and they went to their tents.
verses.comment: Simple modern past tense phrasing.

verses.text: To half of the tribe of Manasseh Moses had given inheritance in Bashan, but to the other half Joshua gave inheritance among their brothers west of the Jordan. So when Joshua sent them to their tents, he blessed them.
verses.comment: Explanation of the division of Manasseh is clarified.

verses.text: He spoke to them, saying, “Return with great riches to your tents, with very much livestock, silver, gold, bronze, iron, and with much clothing. Divide the spoil of your enemies with your brothers.”
verses.comment: ‘Spoil’ for plunder is maintained.

verses.text: So the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh left the Israelites at Shiloh in the land of Canaan, to go to the land of Gilead, the land of their inheritance, which they had possessed according to the commandment of the LORD through Moses.
verses.comment: The order of description follows the original closely.

verses.text: When they came to the region near the Jordan that is in the land of Canaan, the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh built there an altar by the Jordan, a large and imposing altar.
verses.comment: ‘Large and imposing’ clarifies ‘great to the sight’.

verses.text: And the Israelites heard it said, “Behold, the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh have built an altar opposite the land of Canaan, in the region near the Jordan, on the side belonging to the Israelites.”
verses.comment: ‘Opposite the land of Canaan’ clarifies the altar’s location.

verses.text: When the Israelites heard of it, the whole assembly of the children of Israel gathered at Shiloh to go to war against them.
verses.comment: ‘Assembly’ refers to the formal gathering of the tribes.

verses.text: The children of Israel sent Phinehas son of Eleazar the priest to the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead,
verses.comment: Phinehas as the mediator is historically confirmed.

verses.text: and with him ten chiefs, one leader from each of the tribal families of Israel, each one head of a house among the clans of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Chiefs’ translates ‘princes’ for modern clarity.

verses.text: They came to the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead, and spoke to them, saying:
verses.comment: Sentence compression for improved readability.

verses.text: “This is what the whole assembly of the LORD says: ‘Why have you broken faith with the God of Israel by turning away from following the LORD, and by building yourselves an altar, so that you would rebel this day against the LORD?
verses.comment: ‘Broken faith’ commonly translates ‘commit trespass’ for clarity.

verses.text: Was not the sin at Peor enough for us, from which we are not yet cleansed to this day, even though there was a plague among the assembly of the LORD?
verses.comment: Reference to ‘sin at Peor’ connects to Numbers 25 event.

verses.text: And yet you are turning away this day from following the LORD! If you rebel today against the LORD, He will be angry with all the congregation of Israel tomorrow.
verses.comment: ‘Angry with all the congregation’ brings the nuance of corporate holiness.

verses.text: If the land of your possession is unclean, then cross over into the land of the possession of the LORD, where the LORD’s tabernacle stands, and take possession among us. But do not rebel against the LORD, nor rebel against us by building yourselves an altar besides the altar of the LORD our God.
verses.comment: Distinction between the two lands is maintained.

verses.text: Did not Achan son of Zerah break faith concerning the devoted thing, and wrath fell upon all the congregation of Israel? Achan was not the only one who died for his sin.’”
verses.comment: ‘Devoted thing’ retains the technical term for ‘herem’ objects.

verses.text: Then the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh answered and spoke to the leaders of the tribes of Israel:
verses.comment: ‘Leaders’ modernizes ‘heads of the thousands of Israel.’

verses.text: “The Mighty One, God, the LORD! The Mighty One, God, the LORD! He knows, and may Israel know. If it was in rebellion, or betrayal against the LORD, do not spare us this day.
verses.comment: Trifold address of God is maintained as a proclamation of divine witness.

verses.text: If we have built ourselves an altar to turn away from the LORD, or to offer burnt offerings or grain offerings on it, or to offer peace offerings on it, may the LORD Himself hold us accountable.
verses.comment: Explicit mention of all offerings clarifies possible offenses.

verses.text: But in fact, we did it out of concern, thinking, ‘In time to come your children might say to our children, “What have you to do with the LORD, the God of Israel?”’
verses.comment: ‘Out of concern’ clarifies the original ‘out of fear’.

verses.text: For the LORD has made the Jordan a border between us and you, the children of Reuben and Gad. You have no share in the LORD.’ So your children might discourage our children from fearing the LORD.
verses.comment: The sense of ‘discourage’ fits the Hebrew ‘cause to cease from’.

verses.text: So we said, ‘Let us get ready and build an altar, not for burnt offering or for sacrifice,
verses.comment: Clarification: not an altar for sacrifice.

verses.text: but to be a witness between us and you, and between the generations after us, that we may worship before the LORD with our burnt offerings, sacrifices, and peace offerings; then your children would not say to our children in time to come, ‘You have no share in the LORD.’”
verses.comment: The nature of the altar as a ‘witness’ is emphasized.

verses.text: Therefore, we said, ‘If they say this to us or to our descendants in the future, we will reply, “See the replica of the altar of the LORD which our fathers made, not for burnt offering or for sacrifice, but as a witness between us and you.”’
verses.comment: ‘Replica’ clarifies ‘pattern’ or ‘copy’ for modern readers.

verses.text: Far be it from us to rebel against the LORD, and to turn away today from following the LORD, by building an altar for burnt offerings, grain offerings, or sacrifices, other than the altar of the LORD our God that stands before His tabernacle!”
verses.comment: Maintains technical description for offerings.

verses.text: When Phinehas the priest and the leaders of the assembly, the heads of the tribes of Israel who were with him, heard the words the descendants of Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh spoke, it pleased them.
verses.comment: ‘Pleased them’ modernizes ‘it was good in their eyes’.

verses.text: Phinehas son of Eleazar the priest said to the descendants of Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh, “Today we know that the LORD is among us, because you have not broken faith with the LORD. Therefore you have delivered the children of Israel from the hand of the LORD.”
verses.comment: ‘Hand of the LORD’ refers to His wrath; idiom maintained.

verses.text: Then Phinehas son of Eleazar the priest and the leaders returned from the children of Reuben and Gad in the land of Gilead to the Israelites in the land of Canaan, and brought back word to them.
verses.comment: ‘Brought back word’ is faithful to ‘reported to them’.

verses.text: The Israelites were glad, and blessed God. They spoke no more of going to war against them to destroy the land where the children of Reuben and Gad lived.
verses.comment: Resolved with peace; ‘destroy the land’ reflects original threat.

verses.text: The children of Reuben and the children of Gad called the altar 'Witness', for they said, “It is a witness between us that the LORD is God.”
verses.comment: The name ‘Witness’ is given as in the original ('Ed' in Hebrew).
